headline: US oil giants say it's early days on potential Venezuela boom
summary:
ExxonMobil and Chevron said Friday that they were awaiting signs of greater fiscal and legal stability in Venezuela before significantly shifting their approach to the oil-rich country.- 'Stability' -
Chevron, the only US oil company that has continued to operate in Venezuela, believes the country "has the opportunity to become a more sizable part of our portfolio in the future," said CEO Mike Wirth on an conference call with analysts.

headline: Chevron And Exxon Top Earnings But Only One Supermajor Saw Profit Growth; U.S. Oil Prices And Venezuela In Focus
summary: Chevron and Exxon Mobil both reported fourth-quarter earnings and revenue before Friday's stock market open.  Exxon Mobil notched its first quarterly profit increase in more than a year and enters Friday's stock market trading around record highs.  Exxon Mobil reported Friday that Q4 EPS increased 2.4% to $1.71, while revenue declined 1.3% to $82.31 billion.

headline: Exxon Mobil reports strong quarterly profit on solid production at home and abroad
summary: Exxon Mobil topped most expectations in the fourth quarter as the energy giant reported solid production in the Permian Basin and Guyana.  For the three months ended Dec. 31, Exxon earned $6.5 billion, or $1.53 per share.  Excluding one time charges and benefits earnings were $1.71 per share, topping the $1.68 per share that Wall Street was calling for, according to a poll by Zacks Investment Research.

headline: Exxon: Q4 Earnings Snapshot
summary: The Spring, Texas-based company said it had net income of $1.53 per share. Earnings, adjusted for one-time gains and costs, were $1.71 per share. The results surpassed Wall Street expectations, but Exxon does not adjust its reported results based on one-time events such as asset sales.

headline: US eases sanctions after Venezuela passes oil law reforms
summary: STORY: Venezuela has approved a sweeping reform of its main oil law, a fast‑tracked move aimed at reviving the country’s ailing energy industry.Lawmakers on Thursday (January 29) backed interim President Delcy Rodriguez’s proposal to lower taxes, expand the oil ministry’s powers, and grant long‑sought autonomy to private producers.The changes also open the door to transferring assets currently controlled by state oil company PDVSA.:: FileThe reform comes as U.S. President Donald Trump pushes a $100 billion reconstruction plan for Venezuela’s oil sector, following the capture of President Nicolás Maduro earlier this month.Washington eased sanctions on Venezuelan crude exports shortly after the reform passed.The new law reverses two decades of strict nationalization that drove foreign majors like Exxon and ConocoPhillips out of the country.Potential investors have described it as "good enough", though some former Venezuela officials say it's unconstitutional. The government is expected to evaluate dozens of existing oil joint ventures over the next six months before signing new contracts under the updated model.

raw.headline: US eases sanctions after Venezuela passes oil law reforms
raw.summary: STORY: Venezuela has approved a sweeping reform of its main oil law, a fast‑tracked move aimed at reviving the country’s ailing energy industry.Lawmakers on Thursday (January 29) backed interim President Delcy Rodriguez’s proposal to lower taxes, expand the oil ministry’s powers, and grant long‑sought autonomy to private producers.The changes also open the door to transferring assets currently controlled by state oil company PDVSA.:: FileThe reform comes as U.S. President Donald Trump pushes a $100 billion reconstruction plan for Venezuela’s oil sector, following the capture of President Nicolás Maduro earlier this month.Washington eased sanctions on Venezuelan crude exports shortly after the reform passed.The new law reverses two decades of strict nationalization that drove foreign majors like Exxon and ConocoPhillips out of the country.Potential investors have described it as "good enough", though some former Venezuela officials say it's unconstitutional. The government is expected to evaluate dozens of existing oil joint ventures over the next six months before signing new contracts under the updated model.

headline: Exxon Mobil Shutters Fife Plant As Investors Weigh Valuation And Risks
summary: Exxon Mobil plans to close its Fife Ethylene Plant in Scotland after determining the facility is no longer economically viable. More than 400 jobs are at risk as operations at the site are expected to wind down. The Scottish Government has set up a task force and support funding in response to the closure announcement. For investors watching Exxon Mobil, ticker NYSE:XOM, the move adds a fresh operational shift in Europe to a company already under close scrutiny. The shares most recently...
